comment: Heavy rye up from with a smooth buttery caramel finish
Not sure if this can get much better. Unbelievably smooth. Tons of cherry, vanilla, and cinnamon/apple. Thicccc, motor oil viscosity
Smooth, loooong drag. Sweet caramel finish. Lasts a good while in the mouth.
Nice complexity incredible mouth feel and excellent aftertaste.
Caramel. Rye. Toasted oak. Mellowed with age. Very smooth. Expensive but worth it.
Wow I can’t believe I get to try this! Awesome balanced sweet and spicy rye. 94

N - exceptional, dark chocolate and cherry hints

P - no surprise here, low rolling rye and spice with some sugary notes

F - quite lasting, fades off nicely from the spicy rye 

Reminds me of a milder lot 40 cask strength

Aromas of pine, cinnamon and buttery corn compete for your attention. At times one or the other dominates, but mostly they dance together. Pow - The first mouthful brings a pinpoint delivery of zesty spices that stretch for minutes. Underneath this is a mix of orange and sweet cream. On the finish, those spices stay on the tongue for as long as you can resist another sip. There’s a hint of the creaminess too. 

I love rye but with so much of it coming from MGP or Alberta it can sometimes seem a narrow school. This is very different, with the creaminess almost suggesting a blend of rye and bourbon. Fortunately for this bourbon-skeptic it never strays too far into popcorn territory. As premium ryes go, this is one of the best in recent years.

Nose: Barrel char, chocolate, dusty oak, rich, hint of maple, almond paste
Palate: maple, toasted barrel, red fruits, apple juice
Finish: pineapple, roasted nuts, oak, cinnamon spice
Musty warehouse, sweet tea, cream soda. This is the best rye I've had in 2019. I would rate it even higher if it was bottled at a higher proof.

Big vanilla nose compared to the "regular" last bottle. Also much darker in color. 

This is a neck pour from a new bottle.

The flavors are more smokey, less caramel than the last pour. This also finished hotter than the last. 

Gave it two drops of water. (Only intended for one... oops) I like it less with the water drops. It brings out the smokiness.
Vanilla heavy on the nose, mild spice, minimal heat, buttery smooth.

Barrel #19F1024

Nose: delightful alcohol burn, burnt sugar

Taste: caramel, suggestion of citrus?, vanilla

Tasting Barrel #19F963

Nose - dry oak, dark brown sugar, leather, and a faint evergreen note. Not especially rye-like, I could easily mistake this for a bourbon based on the nose. 

Palate - Caramel corn, dark chocolate, rye spice, some faint spearmint, vanilla and allspice. The finish fades more quickly than I'd like, with some oak and sweetness on the tail end. 

The first time I tasted this, it was a huge disappointment. We'd already had several other whiskeys prior, some of which were considerably higher in proof. In that context the M10 was just dull and thin, with the flavors being very muted. 

I've since revisited it a few times with a fresh palate and my opinion has improved. The flavors/aromas are there to make a compelling whiskey, I just wish it wasn't so subtle. This whiskey is at a 5-6 in intensity, where as I want it to be an 9 or 10. It just really suffers from the low proof, even more so than the M10 Bourbon. I also wish it had more rye character; even for a 'barely-legal' rye this one doesn't have as much of the green notes that you'd expect. I could easily mistake this for a high-rye bourbon rather than a straight rye.

Bottom line, I should have tried this in a bar (if I'd ever seen it), so I could have had the experience without the price of a full bottle. If they ever release the 10yr at barrel strength, I'm sure it would be excellent; but this one is weak-sauce compared to competing ryes.

By far the best Rye I’ve had to date! Was lucky enough to be able to get a bottle when I visited the distiller last fall. I had to choose between this and the bourbon 10 year because I didn’t have the funds to buy both. Went to the bar upstairs tried them both and went with this. My bottle is from barrel no 19F978. Finally cracked it open tonight and I am not disappointed in my decision in the slightest!

I had this at the Waldorf in Orlando and is one of the best bourbons I have tried. At $35 per glass I could not pass it up.  Much less than the $135 per glass for BossHog.  Very smooth and not in your face.  Very crisp and no burn.  Well worth the price!
2016 is the best but 18’ and 19’ are very good.
